I.  THE ENSUING PROJECT 
 
1.  The  Government  of  Mongolia,  during  the  country  programming  mission  held  in 
Ulaanbaatar in April 2019, requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to provide a lending 
support to prepare the Sustainable Tourism Development Project (Phase 2). The ensuing loan is 
included in ADB’s country operations business plan for Mongolia, 2020–2021 and the proposed 
transaction technical assistance (TA) is included in ADB’s nonlending pipeline for 2020.1 
 
2.  Mongolia has a small but growing tourism sector. Government plans to expand the sector 
are focused on nature-based tourism in protected areas (which encompass 21% of Mongolia’s 
area) and cultural heritage. The project will support the development of sustainable tourism within 
three aimags (provinces) of western Mongolia, Bayan-Ulgii, Khovd, and Uvs. The project will have 
four outputs: (i) inclusive planning and capacity for local tourism businesses enhanced; (ii) 
enabling infrastructure for tourism constructed; (iii) sanitation and waste management improved; 
and (iv) management of cultural heritage sites and protected areas strengthened. These outputs 
will result in the following outcome: sustainability and inclusiveness of ecotourism in western 
Mongolia increased. The project outputs will strengthen the institutional framework for tourism 
planning and increase the number of local beneficiaries from tourism; establish a tourism center 
in Uvs Aimag and a rock art and research center in Khovd Aimag, including Mongolia’s first ‘digital 
museum’ for rock art; and install small management facilities at selected cultural heritage sites 
and protected areas e.g., fee collection stations, information signs, elevated walkways, and low-
cost, gender-sensitive toilets. The designs will also address two cross-cutting issues: (i) recovery 
of the local tourism sector from the coronavirus disease outbreak (COVID-19) and measures to 
strengthen the sector from the risk of future disease outbreaks, and (ii) adaptation and/or 
mitigation measures to address the potential impacts of climate change (including extreme floods, 
storms, and harsh winters) to the project structures as well as visitor safety. 
 
3.   The ensuing project will be implemented over 6 years and is estimated to cost $30.3 
million, of which ADB is requested to finance $30.0 million through a project loan. A $2.0 million 
cofinanced grant will be processed in parallel with the loan.2 The central and local governments 
will provide in-kind contribution equivalent to $0.3 million. 
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
4.  The executing agency, the Ministry of Environment and Tourism (MET), has limited 
technical and financial resources to implement the ADB requirements for loan preparation. The 
transaction TA will help the government prepare a project design that complies with the ADB 
requirements and international best practice.3

C.  Cost and Financing 
 
6.  The TA is estimated to cost $0.85 million, of which $0.80 million will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-6). The key expenditure items are 
listed in Appendix 1. 
 
7.  The  government  will  provide  counterpart  support  in  the  form  of  counterpart  staff 
(remuneration and per diems) and their transportation, data collection, administrative and logistic 
support, and other in-kind contributions. The government was informed that approval of the TA 
does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
8.  ADB will administer the TA. The MET will be the executing agency. The Department of 
Tourism Policy Coordination (DTPC) of MET will be the implementing agency for the loan and the 
Department of Protected Area Management (DPAM) will be the implementing agency for the 
grant. The DTPC will coordinate MET and local government support for project preparation. A 
multisector steering committee chaired by MET will provide guidance to the project. The DTPC 
and the DPAM will nominate key focal points that will support the daily TA coordination, including 
facilitation of meetings and site visits and timely government review and feedback on the draft 
project designs. The governments of Bayan-Ulgii, Khovd and Uvs aimags will each assign a 
project focal point, who will coordinate with the executing and implementing agencies and TA

3 
consulting firm for the fieldwork and stakeholder consultations. The TA will be implemented over 
about 11 months, tentatively from June 2020 to April 2021. Equipment for the TA consultants will 
be procured following ADB’s Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and the 
associated Staff Instructions and handed over to MET upon the TA completion. Disbursements 
under the TA will be in line with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as 
amended from time to time).
